sourceDesc.p: Source of current file iswhich was converted from version 09 of the plain XML version of the DBOE

editorialDecl.p: On conversion of phonetic transcriptions: Conversion of the originalTustep/Teutonista phonetic transcriptions are made in stages in copies of the elements with these contents (TEI:pron@notation="tustep", andquote, (originally TUSTEP: *KT*, *LT*, and *LW*). The copied element for IPA conversion all contain the attributes @change, and@resp, the value of @changewill be the number of change processes carried out on the elements contents (each change will be documented with the script or replacements made). The value of @respis the person or persons responsible for the changes. The copiedpronelement also has the attribute-value pair @notation="ipa", even throughout the transitional period during which the reality is that it is a mixture of IPA and Tustep/Teutonista phonetic transcription. Currently the copies ofquotefrom contextual examples of usage of dialect forms (Tustep: *KT*) does not have @notationas this is not allowed in the current TEI guidelines and for the interest of simplicity in the access and sharing of this dataset at least in its early stages, we are deciding not to make alterations to the schema via TEI ODD language. Later steps may choose one of three ways to deal with this: 1)propose changes to the TEI schema allowing @notationto occur inquote; 2) make an ODD and use schema to allow for necessary alterations; 3) use @xml:langaccording to BCP 47 in which we can specify the notation following the language tag. This would however require changes to out current usage of @xml:lang, which for the bavarian dialect data, is simpy declared inentrybecause of certain factors having to do with the legacy structure of the data records. Finally, despite the current inconsistancy in the use of @notationbetween the 3 datatypes being converted to IPA, the altered version of the phonetic transcriptions are (as of this 1st version) nonetheless minimally distinguishable in their XPath by the presence of @change, and@respwithin the same element, be thatpron, orquote.

entry.etym: Aus dem slov. dr-enulja von dr>enz, was wohl aus dervnz stammt, daher verwandt mit dr>evo, bezüglich dessen siehe Walde 325 unter larix: Lad. deren. Vergleiche auch die Anmerkungen von Ko>stial in der Abhandlung "Slovansk.e >zivljc", Program des II. Staatsgymn. 1900/1 in Laibach S. 15. Was Miklosích (Et. Wb. 42 dern - 2) schreibt, ist zuwenig bestimmt, weil er ohne jede Erläuterung nur das ahd. tirnpauma, nhd. dernlein, diernlein und terling anführt. Die deutschen Mundarten kennen noch andere Formen, z.B. bair. Dirnlein (DiE'nl,DiE'l), Dirnleinbeer (DiE'lber), auch Dírliz, Direnzen, direnzenpaum (Schmeller I. 541), das aus dem slov. dr>enuljica. Auch das deutsche Dorlenbaum für das gleiche Gewächs entstand wohl über Einfluß unseres Wortes. Wenn unser Wort ursprünglich deutsch gewesen wäre, müßte es, weil es allen Slaven bekannt ist, "tr>en" tr>enulja lauten, wenn wir das ahd. tirnpauma in Betracht ziehen (berücksichtigen).
